metadata.title: Influence of pretreatment condition of amorphous-type Cu-ZrO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalyst on direct ethyl acetate synthesis from ethanol

Fig. 1 Ethanol conversion and product yields with the reaction time over Cu-ZrO2 pretreated under (a) N2 and (b) 10 % H2 (N2 balance) flow. Catalyst: 200 mg; ethanol: 20 %; N2: balance; total flow rate: 20 mL·min−1; 493 K; 1 atm. Pretreatment: 573 K, 1 h. AcH: acetaldehyde; AcOEt: ethyl acetate; C4-al,ol: sum of saturated/unsaturated C4 alcohols and aldehydes. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Pretreatment condition dependence on (a) ethanol conversion, yields of (b) ethyl acetate, (c) sum of saturated/unsaturated C4 aldehyde and alcohols (C4-al,ol), and (d) acetaldehyde. Samples had been pretreated under N2 stream(Type-A), H2 stream (Type-B) and halfway H2 switching from N2 (Type-C). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Pretreatment condition dependence on product ratio. Samples had been pretreated under N2 stream (Type-A), H2 stream (Type-B) and halfway H2 switching from N2. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts pretreated under different conditions. N-, H-, NH- series samples had been pretreated under N2 stream(Type-A), H2 stream (Type-B) and halfway H2 switching from N2 (Type-C), respectively. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Fourier transforms of Cu K-edge k 3 -weighted EXAFS of spent Cu-ZrO2 catalyst pretreated under different conditions. (a) Type-A pretreated under N2 flow, (b) Type-B pretreated under H2 flow, and (c) Type-C pretreated under N2 flow, changed to a prescribed temperature, followed by changing treatment gas to H2. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Cu K-edge XANES spectra of spent Cu-ZrO2 catalyst pretreated under different conditions. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Results of XAFS analysis of spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts pretreated under different conditions. (a) Estimated fraction of metallic Cu species in spent Cu-ZrO2 by XANES analysis, (b) effective coordination number of metallic Cu-Cu bond by XANES and EXAFS. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 STEM dark-field images of fresh and spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts pretreated under different conditions. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Estimated surface Cu/Zr atomic ratio of fresh and spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts pretreated under different conditions. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Possible scheme of the changing of Cu species in amorphous-type Cu-ZrO2 during pretreatment procedure under H2 flow. Fig. 10 Table 1 Results of curve-fitting analysis of fresh and spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts. Values in parentheses denote standard deviations. Influence of pretreatment condition of amorphous-type Cu-ZrO2 catalyst on direct ethyl acetate synthesis from ethanol Takashi Yamamoto Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization ⁎ Taketo Tone Investigation Formal analysis Hirotaka Mine Investigation Formal analysis Department of Science and Technology, Tokushima University, Tokushima 770-8506, Japan Department of Science and Technology Tokushima University Tokushima 770-8506 Japan Department of Science and Technology, Tokushima University, Tokushima 770-8506, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Amorphous ZrO2-supported copper catalysts promote direct ethanol conversion into ethyl acetate with high yield and high selectivity. Regarding the pretreatment procedure prior to conducting activity tests, effects of reduction treatment with hydrogen, treatment temperature, and hydrogen-exposure procedure on catalyst performance were investigated. The local and/or bulk structural characterization of each catalyst were also carried out by XRD, XANES/EXAFS, XPS and STEM techniques. The optimal pretreatment conditions were heating from room temperature to 573 K under hydrogen gas flow, which resulted in an ethyl acetate/by-products ratio more than twice that previously reported by us. Appropriate pretreatment is the reduction treatment under mild conditions, which increases the amount of small metallic copper species. Crystallization of the amorphous ZrO₂ phase by inappropriate pretreatment procedures decreased the selectivity for ethyl acetate formation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Direct ethyl acetate synthesis Copper ZrO2 Pretreatment condition Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction It is well known that direct synthesis from ethanol has been found to be promoted by copper-based catalysts [1–12], and been investigating intensively. Crystalline phase of ZrO2 has been found to give influence on the ethyl acetate yields and selectivity by Sato; and monoclinic is preferable [9,10]. They proposed the higher ethyl acetate formation rate is associated with high oxygen mobility from the bulk monoclinic phase to copper species. On the other hand, we have investigated the crystalline phase dependency of Cu-ZrO2 using home-made catalyst from the same sources, and confirmed that amorphous-type catalyst exhibited the highest ethyl acetate yield and the selectivity. The order of suitable crystalline phase without any modification was as follows; amorphous-type > > tetragonal-type > monoclinic-type [13]. Based on activity test using acidity- or basicity modified Cu-ZrO2 catalysts, we have proposed monoclinic ZrO2 possesses acid sites to promote the side reaction of acetaldehyde; an intermediate of ethyl-acetate formation; condensation, whereas the acidity of amorphous ZrO2 is insufficient for promote this unfavorable reaction. Recently, Joshi also confirmed amorphous type CuZrOx catalyst exhibited higher selectivity for direct ethyl acetate formation than tetragonal ZrO2 supported catalyst [14]. In our previous study, the utilized catalyst has been pretreated by thermal treatment at 573 K under N2 flow [13]. Any reduction procedure has not been conducted. The large part of supported Cu species on monoclinic- and tetragonal ZrO2 were confirmed to be reduced to metallic Cu after catalytic test at 493 K. The substrate ethanol acts as a reductant, and supported Cu species on the surface are supposed to be easily reducible. Our amorphous catalysts are typically prepared by impregnating amorphous zirconium hydroxide, which has a large surface area, with a copper nitrate solution, followed by calcination at 673 K. The catalyst color is green. We presume large part of Cu species exist inside the bulk in a dispersed form at the atomic level. Our previous XANES characterization suggested that metallic Cu species in the spent catalyst was about 1/4. Almost other researchers have done reduction treatment on Cu-based catalysts for ethanol conversion before activity tests. More suitable pretreatment procedure could improve the catalytic performance of our amorphous-type catalyst. As for the related work, we have investigated the reaction pathway of ethanol conversion into iso-butene over Ga-doped ZrO2 solid solution catalyst and the structure [15,16]. In that study, we had examined catalytic performance of 12 kinds of period-4 element-doped ZrO2 and confirmed that 5 mol% Cu-doped ZrO2 exhibited the highest activity for ethanol dehydrogenation in the presence of 40 % H2O vapor at 573 K. All the catalysts were utilized without any pre-reduction. Then, our previous report about direct ethyl acetate synthesis from ethanol over supported Cu catalyst has been conducted using the same pretreatment method as the study for iso-butene synthesis [13]. In the present study, we examined the suitable pretreatment conditions for amorphous-ZrO2 supported Cu catalyst and could improve ethyl acetate yield and the selectivity. The local structure around Cu was also investigated. 2 Experimental Zirconium hydroxide Zr(OH)x was obtained by hydrolysis of ZrOCl2·8 H2O (Nacalai Tesque, GR) with NH3 aqueous solution at room temperature. The final pH value was adjusted to 10, and the aging time was 12 h. The white precipitate was repeatedly washed with distilled water until Cl− was not detected by AgNO3 test, dried at 383 K for 12 h. The amorphous-type Cu-ZrO2 catalyst [13] was prepared by impregnation of Zr(OH)x with an aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)3·3 H2O (Nacalai) at 353 K, followed by calcination under air flow at 673 K for 3 h. The loading amount was 10 wt% as Cu metal. Any crystalline phases were not detected in the XRD pattern. XRD patterns were recorded with a Miniflex diffractometer (Rigaku) equipped with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation source. Cu K-edge X-ray absorption spectra were recorded with a laboratory-type spectrometer R-XAS Looper (Rigaku) [17] in transmission mode at room temperature. An open-type X-ray tube equipped with a LaB6 filament and a Mo anode, a curved Ge(220) or Ge(440) crystal, an Ar-gas sealed proportional counter, and a scintillation counter were used as the X-ray source, the monochromator crystal for EXAFS or XANES, and detectors for incident and transmitted X-rays, respectively. The data reduction for the EXAFS analysis was performed with the REX2000 program [18]. The phase shift and backscattering amplitudes were calculated using the FEFF8.4 program [19]. For the XANES, background removal and normalization of the spectra were performed using the Igor Pro 6.2 program [20] according to the procedure reported by Tanaka et al. [21]. The energy was not calibrated. A quantitative component analysis for the XANES spectra by a least-squares method was also performed with Microsoft Excel 2021 in the range of 8950 – 9050 eV. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded with a PHI5000 VersaProbe II (ULVAC-PHI) spectrometer, with monochromated Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). STEM-EDS measurement was conducted on the JEM-2100F microscope (JEOL) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer at 200 kV. The catalytic activity test was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor (inner diameter: 8 mm) under atmospheric pressure at 493 K. The ethanol concentration was 20 vol% with N2 as the balance, and the total flow rate was 20 mL·min−1. The substrate was supplied by a plunger pump N-CL-100 (Nihon Seimitsu Kagaku). The product distributions were analyzed using three GC-8A gas chromatographs (Shimadzu) equipped with a flame ionization detector or a TCD. Utilized columns were Gaskuropack 54 (3.0 mm id × 3 m length), PEG-20M (3.0 mm id × 4 m length) and Active Carbon (3.0 mm id × 2 m length). The conversion, the yield of each product and the selectivity were calculated on the carbon basis at 2 h of the reaction time as follows: Conversion = (moles of substrate reacted) / (moles of substrate loaded) × 100% Yield = (carbon in given product) / (carbon loaded in substrate) × 100% Prior to the activity test, 200 mg of each catalyst was pretreated by thermal treatment under 50 mL·min−1 gas flow in the three different conditions as follows; Type-A: a catalyst was heated to 573 or 673 K under N2 flow and held for 1 h; Type-B: a catalyst was heated to a prescribed temperature (493 – 673 K) under 10 % H2/N2 flow and held for 1 h; Type-C: a catalyst was heated to 673 K under N2 flow and held for 1 h, cooled to a prescribed temperature (473 – 673 K), followed by switched to 10 % H2/N2 flow and hold for 1 h. The spent catalyst for Type-A, -B and -C after the activity test is denoted as N-X, H-X and NH-X, respectively. Here, X represents the treatment temperature. The heating rate from room temperature to a prescribed temperature was 5 K·min−1. 3 Results 3.1 Activity test As described in the Introduction section, our previous activity about ethanol conversion over copper-zirconia catalysts was examined in which pretreatment was conducted by thermal treatment at 573 K under nitrogen flow at 573 K. As shown in Fig. 1, the ethanol conversion and ethyl acetate yield increased when pretreatment was done under H2-N2 stream. We next examined the pretreatment conditions in more detail using three different procedures. Type-A was done under N2 flow (N-X; X = 573 or 673 K), as in previous study. Type-B was done under 10 % H2 flow (H-X; X = 423, 473, 573, 623, 673 K). Type-C was done under N2 flow at 673 K 1 h, cooled to a prescribed temperature, followed by switching flow-gas composition to 10 % H2 (NH-X; X = 473, 523, 573, 623, 673 K). The ethanol conversion and yield of main products conducted under these different conditions are summarized in Fig. 2, plotted as a function of processing temperatures. The temperature for Type-C is one at which H2 gas was introduced. Under N2 flow-type pretreatment (A-type), N-573 and N-673 conditions gave the equivalent catalytic results as for ethanol conversion and product yields. The catalyst was prepared by calcination under air flow at 673 K. It shows effects on chemical species and structure of a catalyst are limited in a case nitrogen-pretreatment was done up to 673 K. If this A-type pretreatment was done at lower temperature such as 523 K, we presume the equivalent results would be obtained. The identical catalytic results were observed where the pretreatment was conducted under H2 flow at 493 K. The ethanol conversion and product yields increased with increasing the treatment temperature for the Type-B conditions, and reached maximum around at 573 K. On the other hand, when hydrogen gas was introduced at a specific temperature (Type-C), ethanol conversion decreased significantly as the introduction temperature increased. The yield of ethyl acetate was approximately the same at 473–573 K, but was less than half that of Type-B, which was pretreated under H2 flow. The yields of C4-al,ol (sum of saturated/unsaturated C4 aldehydes and alcohols) and acetaldehyde were the same level independent on the pretreatment conditions. Note that C4-al,ol yields for Type-B condition were slightly less than those for other conditions. Ethyl acetate formation from ethanol over Cu-based heterogenous catalyst is recognized to proceed via acetaldehyde, where addition of ethanol to acetaldehyde read to form ethyl acetate [4,22]. The main by-products are butyl alcohol and aldehydes. The C4-al,ol are formed via self-condensation of acetaldehyde accompanying to successive dehydration/hydrogenation. Then the product ratio ethyl acetate / C4-al,ol could be applicable for the selectivity index of direct ethyl acetate synthesis. The product ratios in the present study were summarized in Fig. 3. The product ratios for Type-B in the 493 – 573 K of the treatment temperature were more than 2–3 time higher than those for Type-A and Type-C conditions. It clearly shows that Type-B pretreatment is suitable for selective ethyl acetate synthesis, and the optimum temperature is 573 K. 3.2 Characterization 3.2.1 XRD Fig. 4 shows XRD patterns of spent catalyst. The fresh Cu-ZrO2 catalyst is the X-ray amorphous materials, and only a halo was observed around 28–35 degree in the XRD pattern. As previously reported, only a trace level of diffraction lines due to metallic copper was observed in the XRD pattern of the spent catalyst at around 43 degree when pretreatment was conducted under N2 flow at 573 K (N-573). Diffraction lines due to metallic copper were also trace level for Type-B condition (H2 flow) where treatment temperature was up to 623 K. In the case for H-673, formation of crystalline Cu particle was confirmed. Weak diffraction lines due to tetragonal ZrO2 were also observed overlapping with the halo. It should be noted that distinct diffraction lines due to metallic copper were clearly observed in the NH-type catalyst, and their intensity increased with the halfway hydrogen switching temperature. Sharp diffraction lines due to monoclinic ZrO2 are appeared at 673 K of the switching temperature (NH-673). 3.2.2 XAFS Fig. 5 shows radial structure functions (RSFs) of fresh and spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts obtained by Fourier transformation of k 3-weighted Cu K-edge EXAFS. The first coordination sphere of the fresh catalyst could be seen in the RSF around 1.5 Å due to Cu-O pair (Fig. 5(a)). A small peak also could be seen around 2.5 Å. The N-573 and N-673 samples (Type-A) were pretreated under N2 flow condition as the same as the previous study, each the signal level around 2 Å was slightly higher than that of fresh catalyst. It might be reasonable to consider that there is little change before and after the reaction. The peak intensity around 2.2 Å for Type-B samples, where pretreatment was conducted under H2 flow, became larger than those for Type-A, and increased with the treatment temperature. In cases for Type-C of halfway H2 switching samples, distinct large peak could be confirmed for NH-673. The spectral shape is similar to that of Cu foil although the intensity was almost the half level. This distinct peak could be confirmed for Type-C samples even at temperatures below 623 K. The peaks for the first coordination sphere were smaller but also be seen confirmed. Results of curve-fitting analysis are summarized in Table 1. The first and second coordination sphere of spent catalysts observed in each RSFs could be confirmed Cu-O and Cu-Cu pairs, respectively. The bond length for Cu-Cu pair is similar to that of Cu foil, suggesting that Cu species in spent catalysts are mixture of metallic and cationic species. The second coordination sphere of a fresh catalyst could be fitted as Cu-O pairs, but reliable fitting could not be obtained for Cu-Cu pair. Similarly, it was found that the second coordination sphere of the spent catalyst was not a Cu-O pair. This evidence is consistent with our previous analysis [13] that XANES spectrum equivalent with N-573 was reproducible as a linear combination of a spectrum for metallic copper and one for fresh catalyst. Fig. 6 shows Cu K-edge XANES spectra of a series of spent catalysts. Spectral shape of all the spent catalysts except for NH-673 were not so changed from the fresh catalyst, while tiny band appeared around 8980–8990 region. The XANES spectra of spent catalysts could be reproduced by linear combination of those of Cu foil and a fresh Cu-ZrO2 catalyst. Typical result of the least-squares analysis, and estimated fraction of metal species are summarized in also shown in Fig. 7. Results of curve-fitting analysis shown in Table 1 reflects on the averaged information of all Cu species in catalyst samples. The obtained coordination number (CN) of Cu-Cu pair should be underestimated in cases Cu species is a mixture of aggregated metallic species and cationic species. Then, the original CN of the average value was divided by the estimated fraction of metal to obtain the effective value specific to the metal particles. The corrected CN’s are also shown in Fig. 7. As expected by spectral shape of XANES, fraction of metal for many spent catalysts were less than 40 %. The metallic fraction increased when either the sample was of C-type or the reduction temperature was 673 K. The fractions for A-type were as low as about 25 %. The effective CN of Cu-Cu pair were about 3, 5.5, and 6.5 for A-, B-, C-type spent catalyst samples. In general, as the particle size of metal nanoparticles increases, the coordination number of metal-metal bonds determined by EXAFS analysis also increases. It suggests particle size of the Type-C was larger than those of Type-A and C spent catalyst. XRD patterns of Type-C NH-X catalysts possess sharp and intense peak due to metallic Cu. Then quite larger Cu particle should exist on Type-C catalysts than those for Type-A and -C catalysts. 3.2.3 STEM-EDS Fig. 8 shows STEM dark-field images of fresh and spent Cu-ZrO2 catalysts pretreated under different conditions. In most samples, copper and zirconium species were uniformly dispersed. In cases for N-673, NH-573 and NH-673, however, copper species confirmed to be locally concentrated. It shows aggregated species exist on NH-573 and NH-673 of type-C samples, and the size were about 100 nm at maximum. The size of concentrated Cu species in N-673 was less than 40 nm. 3.2.4 XPS To investigate surface composition of a catalyst, XPS characterization was conducted for fresh and spent Cu-ZrO2 catalyst samples. Using peak area for Zr 3d and Cu 2p, and the relative sensitive factors installed in the apparatus, the Cu/Zr atomic ratio was estimated. The results are summarized in Fig. 9. The surface atomic Cu/Zr ratio of the fresh catalyst was increased more than 1.5 times in all spent catalysts. A detailed analysis revealed that the concentration ratio tended to increase with treatment temperature, and this trend was particularly pronounced in NH-X of type-C samples. Note that no satellite features were observed in the Cu 2p spectra of the catalysts after the activity test. 4 Discussion As mentioned above, our previous study of ethanol conversion by various kinds of Cu-ZrO2 catalysts had been carried out without pre-reducing procedures. The Cu species in the fresh catalyst were divalent, and were reduced during the activity test at 493 K. The fraction of metallic Cu in spent catalysts were estimated by XANES characterization to be ca. 25 and > 90 % for amorphous- and monoclinic-type Cu-ZrO2 catalysts, respectively [13]. Regarding the reason why the proportion of metal species in the highly active and selective amorphous catalyst was low, we presume that copper species were incorporated inside the bulk phase during the catalyst preparation procedure. Only the copper species locating near the surface would be reduced to metal species for Type-A pretreatment without H2 reduction. The H2 pretreatment would surely reduce copper species located in more internal positions and/or less reducible ones. Metallic copper is known to promote alcohol dehydrogenation effectively, and it is possible that increase in the fraction of metallic Cu will improve the ethanol conversion. XRD pattens shown in Fig. 2 shows larger Cu metal particle formed by thermal treatment at 673 K. suggesting that larger particle size might be corresponding to decrease in the net surface area. Based on our previous activity test using acidity- or basicity modified Cu-ZrO2 catalysts, we presume acetaldehyde dimerization of the unfavorable reaction for ethyl acetate synthesis was promoted on acid site of ZrO2, as previously reported [4,12,23]. We also presumed that acidity of monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) is higher than of amorphous ZrO2, and the acid site on m-ZrO2 responsible for lower selectivity for ethyl acetate synthesis due to promotion of acetaldehyde dimerization. Most catalysts utilized in the present study remained X-ray amorphous regardless of the pretreatment conditions, suggesting that the surface acidity be the same level. As the result, the C4-al,ol formation capability did not change significantly. It has been reported that the interface between metallic Cu and ZrO2, and surface acid-base property characteristics to ZrO2 is considered to key issue for ethyl acetate formation [10,24,25]. We have carried out activity test of Cu catalyst supported on 15 kinds of acid-base metal oxides for ethanol conversion, and reconfirmed ZrO2 supported catalyst exhibited particularly high ethyl acetate yield and the selectivity as known [13]. It is well known ZrO2 has the characteristic of coexisting acid and base sites [26–29]. Although the characteristic is also common to rare earth oxides, we have confirmed La2O3 and Y2O3 supported Cu catalyst do not promote ethyl acetate formation. It suggests that it is not sufficient for the support materials to have an acid-base pair site. A detailed evaluation of the acid–base properties is currently underway, and the results will be reported in a forthcoming publication. We suppose that halfway H2 switching Type-C pretreatment procedure cause the rapid temperature rise of a catalyst just after hydrogen introduction. The higher temperatures could cause aggregation Cu0 species to form large particle and crystallization of amorphous-zirconia phase. The effective surface area of Cu metal and the site number of interfaces between metallic Cu and ZrO2 decrease as particle size increases, resulting in a decrease in the catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 1, support ZrO2 phase for NH-673 sample was change to monoclinic. Our assumption is that monoclinic ZrO2 promotes acetaldehyde dimerization as the side reaction more than amorphous ZrO2. This is the reason why the product ratio related to ethyl acetate selectivity over Cu-ZrO2 drastically decreased in the case for NH-673 pretreatment conditions. Incases a fresh catalyst was heated from room temperature to a prescribed temperature (493 – 673 K) under 10 % H2/N2 flow at a heating rate of 5 K·min−1 (Type-B. H-X sample), Cu2+ species inside bulk of amorphous ZrO2 was reduced gently without abrupt temperature raising. As the result, particle size of formed metallic Cu would be smaller than those for Type-C samples. STEM and XANES/EXAFS characterization support this deduction. We presume the Cu species in the present fresh amorphous-type Cu-ZrO2 catalyst exist inside the bulk without aggregation. XPS characterization suggests some part of Cu species near the surface was migrated to surface to form metallic species during the present H2 pre-treatment and/or the activity test. The H2 reduction treatment increased the fraction of reduced Cu species. The schematic image of an amorphous-type Cu-ZrO2 catalyst during pretreatment procedure under H2 flow is shown in Fig. 10. The optimum temperature was determined to be 573 K. Based on the coordination numbers shown in Fig. 7, the most plausible order of the true copper particle sizes is Type-A < -B < < -C. We guess the number of interfaces between metallic copper and ZrO2 surface was maximized at the appropriate particle size, and then both the ethyl acetate yield and the selectivity were improved. The removal of large amounts of Cu2+ species from the amorphous Cu-ZrO2 phase by higher temperature reduction than 623 K might responsible for the crystallization. At present, we have not determined the number of exposed copper surfaces, evaluated the reducibility of the copper species. We would conduct examination about theses issue in the future, and like to clarify the detailed of the influence of pretreatment conditions on the direct ethyl acetate synthesis. 5 Conclusion The effect of pretreatment temperature on direct ethyl acetate synthesis from ethanol over amorphous Cu–ZrO₂ catalysts was systematically investigated. Compared to thermal pretreatment under a nitrogen atmosphere as reported in our previous studies, gradual heating up to 573 K under hydrogen flow led to a 1.5-fold increase in ethyl acetate yield. Moreover, the product ratio of ethyl acetate to side products (butyl alcohols/aldehydes) increased by more than twofold. Copper species dispersed inside the zirconia bulk exhibited low reducibility, and even after hydrogen pretreatment at 573 K, the fraction of metallic copper remained as low as around 25 %. Hydrogen pretreatment promoted the migration of copper species toward the surface, facilitating the formation of metallic copper particles with appropriate size. In contrast, introducing hydrogen at a fixed elevated temperature resulted in excessive particle growth, which adversely affected both yield and selectivity. These findings highlight the importance of conducting the reduction process in a controlled and gradual manner to optimize catalytic performance. In the present study, we optimized the pretreatment conditions of direct ethyl acetate synthesis. The number of surface-exposed metallic copper species is considered a key factor contributing to this performance, and we plan to quantify it in future work using chemisorption experiments. coredata.dc:description: Amorphous ZrO2-supported copper catalysts promote direct ethanol conversion into ethyl acetate with high yield and high selectivity. Regarding the pretreatment procedure prior to conducting activity tests, effects of reduction treatment with hydrogen, treatment temperature, and hydrogen-exposure procedure on catalyst performance were investigated. The local and/or bulk structural characterization of each catalyst were also carried out by XRD, XANES/EXAFS, XPS and STEM techniques. The optimal pretreatment conditions were heating from room temperature to 573 K under hydrogen gas flow, which resulted in an ethyl acetate/by-products ratio more than twice that previously reported by us. Appropriate pretreatment is the reduction treatment under mild conditions, which increases the amount of small metallic copper species. Crystallization of the amorphous ZrO₂ phase by inappropriate pretreatment procedures decreased the selectivity for ethyl acetate formation.

coredata.dc:title: Influence of pretreatment condition of amorphous-type Cu-ZrO2 catalyst on direct ethyl acetate synthesis from ethanol
